pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 206, 332, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 186, 907, 243]]<|/det|>
0625/12 May/June 2017 45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 247, 588, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 352, 237, 367]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 367, 504, 382]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 382, 892, 412]]<|/det|>
Write your name, Centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 410, 384, 425]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 439, 892, 469]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 469, 890, 485]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 556, 515]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 764, 544]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 467, 559]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 559, 364, 574]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 573, 630, 589]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
Which device is used to measure the time it takes for a \(10 \text{cm}^3\) block of ice to melt in a laboratory at room temperature?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 114, 134, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 114, 311, 133]]<|/det|>
measuring cylinder

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 141, 134, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 141, 193, 158]]<|/det|>
ruler

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 166, 133, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 166, 240, 184]]<|/det|>
stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 192, 133, 210]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 192, 260, 210]]<|/det|>
thermometer

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 237, 96, 255]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 237, 888, 255]]<|/det|>
A student determines the average speed of a bubble rising through a liquid at constant speed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 656, 286]]<|/det|>
When the student starts the stopwatch the bubble is at position P.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 298, 425, 316]]<|/det|>
After 2.0 s the bubble is at position Q.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 324, 616, 670]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 682, 541, 701]]<|/det|>
What is the speed of the bubble between P and Q?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 712, 134, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 712, 230, 730]]<|/det|>
3.2 cm/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 712, 303, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[318, 712, 396, 730]]<|/det|>
3.7 cm/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 712, 470, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 712, 562, 730]]<|/det|>
6.4 cm/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 712, 636, 730]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 712, 730, 730]]<|/det|>
7.4 cm/s

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 576, 91]]<|/det|>
The speed-time graph represents a motorcycle journey.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 606, 120]]<|/det|>
In which part of the graph is the acceleration equal to zero?

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 128, 803, 320]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 348, 97, 367]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 348, 628, 367]]<|/det|>
Which expression is used to find gravitational field strength \(g?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 378, 134, 396]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 378, 280, 396]]<|/det|>
mass \(\times\) density

<label>C</label>

weight \(\times\) mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 460, 133, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 460, 275, 479]]<|/det|>
weight \(\div\) mass

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 505, 96, 523]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 504, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
A block of ice is removed from a freezer. Some of the ice melts to produce water. Some of the water that is produced evaporates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 549, 922, 583]]<|/det|>
The original mass of the ice is \(p\). The mass of the ice that has not yet melted is \(q\). The mass of the water is \(r\). The mass of the water vapour is \(s\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 594, 411, 612]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows these changes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 623, 319, 642]]<|/det|>
before melting

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[490, 623, 737, 642]]<|/det|>
after melting and evaporation

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 655, 806, 750]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 763, 616, 782]]<|/det|>
Which equation gives the relationship between \(p\), \(q\), \(r\) and \(s?\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 791, 134, 810]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 791, 228, 810]]<|/det|>
\(p = q + r\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 819, 133, 836]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 819, 256, 836]]<|/det|>
\(p = q + r + s\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 845, 133, 863]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 845, 256, 863]]<|/det|>
\(p = q + r - s\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 871, 133, 890]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 871, 230, 890]]<|/det|>
\(p = q + s\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The masses of a measuring cylinder before and after pouring some liquid into it are shown in the diagram.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 336, 134, 355]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 335, 751, 361]]<|/det|>
100 \(\mathrm{g / cm^3}\) 100 \(\mathrm{g / cm^3}\) 180 \(\mathrm{g / cm^3}\) 180 \(\mathrm{g / cm^3}\)

<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[680, 336, 751, 355]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 394, 920, 428]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 602, 134, 619]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 602, 435, 619]]<|/det|>

The diagram shows a conical vessel full of water.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 819, 120]]<|/det|>
The pressure at point X due to the water is \(p\). A point Q is a distance \(h\) above point X.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[384, 128, 613, 233]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 244, 801, 264]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
In diagram 1 a manometer containing mercury (Hg) is connected to a gas tap. The tap is turned off and the mercury is at the same level on both sides.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[288, 114, 836, 330]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 342, 920, 375]]<|/det|>
When the gas supply is turned on, the mercury in the tube connected to the supply falls by \(40 \text{mm}\) and the mercury in the tube open to the atmosphere rises by \(40 \text{mm}\), as shown in diagram 2.

<label>13</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 836, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 561, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 131, 489, 148]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 157, 134, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 157, 650, 175]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 184, 131, 202]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 700, 201]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 210, 527, 227]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 481, 106, 498]]<|/det|>
<label>15</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 481, 777, 498]]<|/det|>
A glass bottle has a metal cap. The cap fits very tightly and is difficult to remove.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 920, 545]]<|/det|>
The cap and the neck of the bottle are dipped in a bowl of hot water. The cap can be removed more easily.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 555, 732, 574]]<|/det|>
What happens to allow the cap to be removed more easily from the bottle?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 584, 134, 602]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 584, 307, 602]]<|/det|>
The cap contracts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 612, 134, 630]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 612, 301, 630]]<|/det|>
The cap expands.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 133, 657]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 640, 371, 657]]<|/det|>
The glass bottle contracts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 666, 134, 683]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 666, 364, 683]]<|/det|>
The glass bottle expands.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>16</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 668, 89]]<|/det|>
Equal masses of two different liquids are put into identical beakers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 856, 120]]<|/det|>
Liquid 1 is heated for 100 s and liquid 2 is heated for 200 s by heaters of the same power.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 131, 492, 149]]<|/det|>
Each liquid has the same rise in temperature.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 156, 833, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 438, 348, 456]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 466, 133, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 466, 589, 485]]<|/det|>
Each beaker of liquid has the same thermal capacity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 494, 133, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 494, 551, 512]]<|/det|>
Each beaker of liquid receives the same energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 520, 133, 539]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 520, 514, 539]]<|/det|>
Liquid 1 receives more energy than liquid 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 547, 133, 565]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 546, 771, 565]]<|/det|>
The thermal capacity of liquid 1 is less than the thermal capacity of liquid 2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 893, 89]]<|/det|> A copper bar and a wooden bar are joined. A piece of paper is wrapped tightly around the join. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> The bar is heated strongly at the centre for a short time, and the paper goes brown on one side only. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 144, 621, 265]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 278, 734, 295]]<|/det|> Which side goes brown, and what does this show about wood and copper? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 308, 609, 437]]<|/det|>
brown sidewoodcopper
Acopperconductorinsulator
Bcopperinsulatorconductor
Cwoodconductorinsulator
Dwoodinsulatorconductor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 376, 89]]<|/det|> What is the purpose of a relay? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 100, 134, 117]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 100, 527, 118]]<|/det|> to change a large voltage into a small voltage <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 125, 133, 144]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 125, 527, 144]]<|/det|> to change a small voltage into a large voltage <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 152, 131, 170]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 151, 561, 170]]<|/det|> to use a large current to switch on a small current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 178, 133, 196]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 178, 561, 196]]<|/det|> to use a small current to switch on a large current <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 222, 106, 241]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 920, 255]]<|/det|> A coil of four loops of wire is placed in a magnetic field. When there is a current, the coil experiences a turning effect. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 267, 751, 285]]<|/det|> Some extra loops of wire are wound on the coil but the current is unchanged. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 298, 440, 316]]<|/det|> How does this affect the turning effect? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 133, 345]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 327, 285, 345]]<|/det|> It is unchanged. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 352, 133, 371]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 352, 329, 370]]<|/det|> Its direction changes. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 378, 133, 396]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 378, 260, 396]]<|/det|> It decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 405, 133, 422]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 405, 255, 422]]<|/det|> It increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 448, 106, 467]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 448, 435, 467]]<|/det|> Which particle has a negative charge? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 476, 133, 495]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 476, 292, 495]]<|/det|> an alpha particle <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 504, 133, 521]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 504, 248, 521]]<|/det|> an electron <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 530, 133, 548]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 530, 235, 548]]<|/det|> a neutron <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 556, 133, 574]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 556, 225, 574]]<|/det|> a proton <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 600, 106, 618]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 600, 794, 618]]<|/det|> The diagram represents the nucleus of an atom.
